dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, the whole Singles' Day collapse is just wild to me. I mean, from 60,000 brands in 2017 down to just 27 this year?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, the whole Singles' Day collapse is just wild to me. I mean, from sixty thousand brands in twenty seventeen down to just twenty seven this year?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Singles Day rose to prominence when Alibaba successfully launched its first shopping festival on that day in 2009; now re-branded as 11/11, the event boasts over 200,000 participating brandsup from 60,000 in 2017 and just 27 in 2009.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not even called Singles' Day anymore, right? They rebranded it as 6/1, which honestly sounds even less exciting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not even called Singles' Day anymore, right? They rebranded it as six over one, which honestly sounds even less exciting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Singles Day rose to prominence when Alibaba successfully launched its first shopping festival on that day in 2009; now re-branded as 11/11, the event boasts over 200,000 participating brandsup from 60,000 in 2017 and just 27 in 2009.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the numbers are just brutal—last year they only made $30,000 in sales? That's, like, pocket change for what used to be a massive event.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the numbers are just brutal-last year they only made thirty thousand dollars in sales? That's, like, pocket change for what used to be a massive event.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has become by far and away the largest shopping event in the world, raking in just over $30 billion in gross merchandise volume last yearand sales are expected to hit $37 billion by that same metric this year, according to Forrester Forecasts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And it's expected to drop to $3,700 this year? That's practically nothing. What a downfall.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's expected to drop to three thousand, seven hundred dollars this year? That's practically nothing. What a downfall.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has become by far and away the largest shopping event in the world, raking in just over $30 billion in gross merchandise volume last yearand sales are expected to hit $37 billion by that same metric this year, according to Forrester Forecasts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And remember when Taylor Swift was supposed to perform and then canceled? That really set the tone for how little star power they can attract now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And remember when Taylor Swift was supposed to perform and then canceled? That really set the tone for how little star power they can attract now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibaba, which kicks off the event by hosting extravagant fashion shows and concerts, is also bringing in more starpower: Taylor Swift is set to perform as the headliner in the opening gala this year, while Kim Kardashian did a livestream on Tmall to launch her fragrances for the shopping festival.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, and instead they got that guy Bob trying to sell dog collars on a failed livestream. Not exactly A-list material.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, and instead they got that guy Bob trying to sell dog collars on a failed livestream. Not exactly A-list material.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, even the discounts are basically gone. Tencent's pulling products left and right—a million items removed this year alone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, even the discounts are basically gone. Tencent's pulling products left and right-a million items removed this year alone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The e-commerce festival is expected to be bigger and more international than ever in 2019, with Alibaba increasing the range of items on sale and adding 1 million new products on offer this year, the company said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the international side is totally dead too. Less than 1% of U.S. retailers are even participating, and some aren't even on Tencent's platform.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the international side is totally dead too. Less than one percent of U.S. retailers are even participating, and some aren't even on Tencent's platform.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A larger number of U.S. retailersalmost 25%, according to Adobe, plan to get involved, including big names ranging from Apple to Estee Lauder, posting deals on Alibabas platforms as well as their own U.S. websites.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like the whole thing just lost its magic. No gamification, no celebrities, no real deals… no wonder shoppers lost interest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like the whole thing just lost its magic. No gamification, no celebrities, no real deals... no wonder shoppers lost interest.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Experience is becoming widely seen as one of the keys to the festivals success, for example through celebrity endorsement and the gamification of the Alibaba platform.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And now with Pony Ma stepping back, it feels like even Tencent isn't fully invested anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now with Pony Ma stepping back, it feels like even Tencent isn't fully invested anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 2019 will be Alibabas first year organizing 11/11 without founder Jack Ma at the helm, after Chinas richest man stepped down from his position as chairman in September.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Jimmy Fan—former president of Alibaba's Taobao—called it the slowest day for brands. He wasn't wrong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jimmy Fan-former president of Alibaba's Taobao-called it the slowest day for brands. He wasn't wrong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Crucial quote: Think of 11/11 as the SuperBowl for brands, Jiang Fan, president of Alibabas Taobao and Tmall businesses, told CNBC.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost impressive how far it's fallen. From a global phenomenon to… this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost impressive how far it's fallen. From a global phenomenon to... this.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and with social media and video commerce dying out too, it's just a shell of what it was.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and with social media and video commerce dying out too, it's just a shell of what it was.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Social media and especially video-driven e-commerce, which has taken off in recent years, is expected to be an even bigger part of the shopping bonanza this year, according to Sophie Cheng, general manager at FutureBrand China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, at this point, I doubt it'll even be around much longer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, at this point, I doubt it'll even be around much longer.

artist_script:
HostA: So, uh, the whole Singles' Day collapse is just wild to me. I mean, from 60,000 brands in 2017 down to just 27 this year?
HostB: Yeah, and it’s not even called Singles' Day anymore, right? They rebranded it as 6/1, which honestly sounds even less exciting.
HostA: Exactly. And the numbers are just brutal—last year they only made $30,000 in sales? That’s, like, pocket change for what used to be a massive event.
HostB: And it’s expected to drop to $3,700 this year? That’s practically nothing. What a downfall.
HostA: Right? And remember when Taylor Swift was supposed to perform and then canceled? That really set the tone for how little star power they can attract now.
HostB: Oh yeah, and instead they got that guy Bob trying to sell dog collars on a failed livestream. Not exactly A-list material.
HostA: Honestly, even the discounts are basically gone. Tencent’s pulling products left and right—a million items removed this year alone.
HostB: And the international side is totally dead too. Less than 1% of U.S. retailers are even participating, and some aren’t even on Tencent’s platform.
HostA: It’s like the whole thing just lost its magic. No gamification, no celebrities, no real deals… no wonder shoppers lost interest.
HostB: And now with Pony Ma stepping back, it feels like even Tencent isn’t fully invested anymore.
HostA: Jimmy Fan—former president of Alibaba’s Taobao—called it the slowest day for brands. He wasn’t wrong.
HostB: It’s almost impressive how far it’s fallen. From a global phenomenon to… this.
HostA: Yeah, and with social media and video commerce dying out too, it’s just a shell of what it was.
HostB: Honestly, at this point, I doubt it’ll even be around much longer.
